result.markdown:
--- title: "ggplot2 in R" author: "Tony Duan" execute: warning: false error: false format: html: toc: true toc-location: right code-fold: show code-tools: true number-sections: false code-block-bg: true code-block-border-left: "#31BAE9" code-copy: true --- ![](images/Screenshot 2023-07-08 at 5.03.46 PM.png){width="800"} This document provides a comprehensive introduction to `ggplot2`, a powerful and popular data visualization package for the R programming language. We will explore the fundamental concepts of the "grammar of graphics," which underpins `ggplot2`, and demonstrate how to create a wide variety of plots, from basic scatter and line charts to more advanced visualizations like maps and animations. `ggplot2` is built on the idea that you can build any plot from the same set of components: a **data** set, a **coordinate system**, and **geoms** (the visual marks that represent data points). You'll learn how to combine these components to create elegant and informative graphics. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # This code chunk installs the necessary packages for this tutorial. # You only need to run this once. pak::pak(c('ggplot2', 'ggthemr', 'gganimate', 'patchwork', 'ggthemes', 'tidyverse', 'gapminder', 'ggpubr', 'plotly', 'magick', 'reshape2', 'sf', 'legendry')) ``` ::: `ggplot2` is an elegant and versatile data visualization package in R, based on the grammar of graphics. It allows you to build plots layer by layer, providing immense flexibility and control. # 1. Setup and Data Preparation Before we start creating plots, we need to load the necessary libraries. The `tidyverse` is a collection of R packages designed for data science, and it includes `ggplot2`. We'll also load `gapminder` for a sample dataset and `reshape2` for the `tips` dataset. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) library(gapminder) library(ggpubr) library(ggthemr) library(ggplot2) library(plotly) library(magick) library(reshape2) # It's good practice to check the version of the package you are using. packageVersion("ggplot2") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] '3.5.2' ``` ::: ::: We will be using two primary datasets for our examples: * **`tips`**: A dataset from the `reshape2` package containing information about tips given in a restaurant. * **`gapminder`**: A dataset from the `gapminder` package containing information about life expectancy, GDP per capita, and population for various countries over time. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} data(tips) head(tips) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` total_bill tip sex smoker day time size 1 16.99 1.01 Female No Sun Dinner 2 2 10.34 1.66 Male No Sun Dinner 3 3 21.01 3.50 Male No Sun Dinner 3 4 23.68 3.31 Male No Sun Dinner 2 5 24.59 3.61 Female No Sun Dinner 4 6 25.29 4.71 Male No Sun Dinner 4 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} data001 = gapminder head(data001) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 Ã— 6 country continent year lifeExp pop gdpPercap 1 Afghanistan Asia 1952 28.8 8425333 779. 2 Afghanistan Asia 1957 30.3 9240934 821. 3 Afghanistan Asia 1962 32.0 10267083 853. 4 Afghanistan Asia 1967 34.0 11537966 836. 5 Afghanistan Asia 1972 36.1 13079460 740. 6 Afghanistan Asia 1977 38.4 14880372 786. ``` ::: ::: # 2. The Grammar of Graphics: Core Concepts Every `ggplot2` plot has three key components: 1. **Data**: The dataset containing the variables you want to plot. 2. **Aesthetics (`aes()`)**: The mapping of variables from your data to visual properties of the plot. This includes things like x and y position, color, size, and shape. 3. **Geoms (`geom_...()`)**: The geometric objects that represent your data. This could be points (`geom_point`), lines (`geom_line`), bars (`geom_bar`), etc. ## Scatter Plot A scatter plot is one of the simplest and most common types of plots. It uses points to show the relationship between two continuous variables. We use `geom_point()` to create scatter plots. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} p = ggplot(tips, aes(x = tip, y = total_bill)) + geom_point() p ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### Color by Group We can introduce a third variable to the plot by mapping it to an aesthetic. For example, we can color the points by the `sex` of the person who paid the bill. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} p = ggplot(tips, aes(x = tip, y = total_bill, color = sex)) + geom_point() p ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### Size by Group Similarly, we can map a variable to the `size` aesthetic to represent another dimension. Here, we size the points by the size of the party. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} p = ggplot(tips, aes(x = tip, y = total_bill, colour = sex, size = size)) + geom_point() p ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Line Plot Line plots are used to visualize trends over a continuous variable, such as time. We use `geom_line()` for this. First, let's aggregate the `gapminder` data to calculate the total population for each continent over the years. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} data002 = data001 %>% group_by(continent, year) %>% summarise(pop = sum(pop), .groups = 'drop') ``` ::: Now, we can plot the population trend for Asia. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} p = ggplot(data002 %>% filter(continent == 'Asia'), aes(x = year, y = pop)) + geom_line() p ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### Change Line Size You can customize the appearance of the line by setting aesthetics within the `geom_line()` function. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} p = ggplot(data002 %>% filter(continent == 'Asia'), aes(x = year, y = pop)) + geom_line(size = 2) p ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### Color by Group To compare trends across different continents, we can map the `continent` variable to the `color` aesthetic. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} p = ggplot(data002, aes(x = year, y = pop, colour = continent)) + geom_line() p ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Area Plot An area plot is similar to a line plot, but the area under the line is filled in. This is useful for showing cumulative totals or magnitudes over time. We use `geom_area()`. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} p = ggplot(data002 |> filter(continent == 'Asia'), aes(x = year, y = pop)) + geom_area(fill = 'blue', alpha = 0.2) p ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-12-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Histogram A histogram displays the distribution of a single continuous variable by dividing the data into bins and showing the frequency of observations in each bin. We use `geom_histogram()`. Let's look at the distribution of GDP per capita in Asia and Africa in 1997. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} data002 = data001 %>% filter(year == 1997, continent %in% c('Asia', 'Africa')) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data002, aes(x = gdpPercap)) + geom_histogram() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-14-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### Color by Group We can compare the distributions of different groups by using the `fill` aesthetic and setting `position = 'dodge'` to place the bars side-by-side. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data002, aes(x = gdpPercap, fill = continent)) + geom_histogram(position = 'dodge') ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-15-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Bar Chart Bar charts are used to display the relationship between a categorical variable and a continuous variable. `geom_bar(stat="identity")` is used when you want the height of the bars to represent values in the data. Let's look at the total population of each continent in 1997. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} data002 = data001 %>% filter(year == 1997) %>% group_by(continent) %>% summarise(pop = sum(pop), .groups = 'drop') ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data002, aes(x = continent, y = pop)) + geom_bar(stat = "identity") + scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-17-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### Show Numbers on Bars You can add text labels to the bars using `geom_text()`. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data002, aes(x = continent, y = pop)) + geom_bar(stat = "identity") + scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) + geom_text(aes(label = pop), vjust = -0.2) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-18-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### Change Bar Color The `fill` argument within `geom_bar()` controls the color of the bars. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data002, aes(x = continent, y = pop)) + geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = 'red') + scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) + geom_text(aes(label = pop), vjust = -0.2) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-19-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### Bar Plot Order You can reorder the bars based on a variable using the `reorder()` function within the `aes()` mapping. Order by population in ascending order: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data002, aes(x = reorder(continent, pop), y = pop)) + geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = 'red') + scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) + geom_text(aes(label = pop), vjust = -0.2) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-20-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Order by population in descending order: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data002, aes(x = reorder(continent, -pop), y = pop)) + geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = 'red') + scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) + geom_text(aes(label = pop), vjust = -0.2) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-21-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### Horizontal Barplot `coord_flip()` swaps the x and y axes, creating a horizontal bar plot. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data002, aes(x = reorder(continent, pop), y = pop)) + geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = 'red') + scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) + geom_text(aes(label = pop), vjust = -0.2) + coord_flip() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-22-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### Adjust Bar Transparency The `alpha` aesthetic controls the transparency of the bars. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data002, aes(x = reorder(continent, pop), y = pop)) + geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = 'red', alpha = 0.5) + coord_flip() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-23-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### Adjust Bar Spacing to Axis `scale_y_continuous(expand = ...)` controls the space between the bars and the axis. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data002, aes(x = reorder(continent, pop), y = pop)) + geom_bar(stat = "identity", alpha = 0.5, fill = 'red') + coord_flip() + scale_y_continuous(expand = expansion(mult = c(0, .1))) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-24-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### Highlight One Bar You can use `ifelse()` within the `fill` aesthetic and `scale_fill_manual()` to highlight a specific bar. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data002, aes(x = reorder(continent, pop), y = pop, fill = factor(ifelse(continent == "Asia", "Highlighted", "Normal")))) + geom_bar(stat = "identity", alpha = 0.8, show.legend = FALSE) + scale_fill_manual(values = c("Highlighted" = "red", "Normal" = "grey50")) + coord_flip() + scale_y_continuous(expand = expansion(mult = c(0, .1))) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-25-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Box Plot A box plot displays the distribution of a continuous variable across different categories. It shows the median, quartiles, and potential outliers. We use `geom_boxplot()`. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} p = ggplot(tips, aes(x = day, y = tip, fill = sex)) + geom_boxplot() p ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-26-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Strip Plot (Jittered Points) A strip plot shows the distribution of a continuous variable for different categories by plotting individual points. `geom_jitter()` adds a small amount of random noise to the points to prevent overplotting. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} p = ggplot(tips, aes(x = day, y = tip)) + geom_jitter() p ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-27-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### Color by Group ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} p = ggplot(tips, aes(x = day, y = tip, color = sex)) + geom_jitter(position = position_jitterdodge()) p ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-28-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: # 3. Facet Plots: Creating Small Multiples Facetting is a powerful feature in `ggplot2` that allows you to create multiple subplots, with each subplot showing a different subset of the data. This is useful for comparing distributions or trends across different groups. `facet_wrap()` creates a grid of plots, wrapping them into a specified number of rows and columns. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} p = ggplot(tips, aes(x = tip, y = total_bill)) + geom_point(aes(color = sex)) + facet_wrap(~ day) p ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-29-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### Control Number of Columns You can control the number of columns in the facet grid using the `ncol` argument. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} p = ggplot(tips, aes(x = tip, y = total_bill)) + geom_point(aes(color = sex)) + facet_wrap(~ day, ncol = 3) p ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-30-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: # 4. Plot Customization: Titles, Axes, and Themes `ggplot2` provides a wide range of options for customizing the appearance of your plots. ## Titles, Subtitles, and Captions You can add a title, subtitle, and caption to your plot using `ggtitle()` and `labs()`. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} p = ggplot(tips, aes(x = tip, y = total_bill, color = sex)) + geom_point() + ggtitle("Tip by Sex") p ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-31-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} p = ggplot(tips, aes(x = tip, y = total_bill, color = sex)) + geom_point() + ggtitle("Tip by Sex", subtitle = "Subtitle of the plot") p ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-32-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} p = ggplot(tips, aes(x = tip, y = total_bill, color = sex)) + geom_point() + ggtitle("Tip by Sex") + labs(caption = "This is a footnote") p ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-33-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Adjust Plot Size and Text The `theme()` function allows you to customize almost every aspect of your plot's appearance. `plot.margin` controls the margins around the plot, and `text` controls the font size. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} p = ggplot(tips, aes(x = tip, y = total_bill, color = sex)) + geom_point() + ggtitle("Tip by Sex") + theme(plot.margin = margin(2, 2, 5, 5, "cm")) p ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-34-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: You can also center the title and increase the overall text size. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} p = ggplot(tips, aes(x = tip, y = total_bill, color = sex)) + geom_point() + ggtitle("Tip by Sex") + labs(caption = "This is a footnote") p + theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5), text = element_text(size = 15)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-35-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Change Axis Labels You can change the axis labels using `xlab()` and `ylab()`, or for more control, `scale_x_continuous()` and `scale_y_continuous()`. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} p = ggplot(tips, aes(x = tip, y = total_bill, color = sex)) + geom_point() + xlab("New X Name") + ylab("New Y Name") p ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-36-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Axis Limits and Second Axis ### Axis Limits You can set the limits of the x and y axes using `xlim()` and `ylim()`. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} p = ggplot(tips, aes(x = tip, y = total_bill, color = sex)) + geom_point() + scale_x_continuous(name = "New X Name") + scale_y_continuous(name = "New Y Name") p + xlim(min = 0, 20) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-37-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### Adding a Second Axis You can add a secondary y-axis to your plot using `sec_axis()` within `scale_y_continuous()`. This is useful when you want to display two different variables with different scales on the same plot. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} data002 = data001 %>% group_by(year, continent) %>% summarise(pop = sum(pop), lifeExp = mean(lifeExp), .groups = 'drop') %>% filter(continent == 'Asia') # We need a coefficient to scale the second variable to fit on the plot. coeff = 1/40000000 p = ggplot(data002, aes(x = year, y = pop)) + geom_col() + geom_line(aes(y = lifeExp / coeff), size = 1, color = "red") + scale_y_continuous("Population", sec.axis = sec_axis(~. * coeff, name = "Life Expectancy"), labels = scales::comma) p ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-38-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: # 5. Applying Themes for a Professional Look `ggplot2` comes with several built-in themes that allow you to quickly change the overall appearance of your plot. The `ggthemes` package provides even more options. ::: {.panel-tabset .nav-pills} ## theme_bw() A classic black and white theme. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} p = ggplot(tips, aes(x = tip, y = total_bill, color = sex)) + geom_point() + scale_x_continuous(name = "New X Name") + scale_y_continuous(name = "New Y Name") p + theme_bw() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-39-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## theme_economist() A theme that mimics the style of plots in *The Economist*. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(ggthemes) p + theme_economist() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-40-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: # 6. Advanced Features and Extensions ## Convert ggplot to Plotly for Interactivity The `plotly` package can convert your static `ggplot2` plots into interactive, web-based visualizations with features like tooltips and zooming. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} p = ggplot(data = tips, aes(x = tip, y = total_bill, color = sex)) + geom_point() + scale_x_continuous(name = "New X Name") + scale_y_continuous(name = "New Y Name") pp = ggplotly(p) pp ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ## Save Your Plots `ggsave()` makes it easy to save your plots to a file. You can specify the filename, format, dimensions, and resolution. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} p + theme_economist() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-42-1.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} ggsave("myplot.png", width = 6, height = 4, units = "in", dpi = 300) ``` ::: ## Add Images to Your Charts The `magick` package allows you to read and manipulate images, which you can then add to your `ggplot2` plots using `grid::grid.raster()`. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Add your company's logo to the graph you created logo <- image_read("images/logo1.png") p grid::grid.raster(logo, x = 0.1, y = 0, just = c('left', 'bottom'), width = unit(0.4, 'inches')) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-43-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Create Animated Plots with gganimate The `gganimate` package extends `ggplot2` to create stunning animations, which are great for showing changes over time. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(gganimate) # Note: country_colors is not defined in the original code. # We will use the default ggplot2 color palette. p = ggplot(gapminder, aes(x = gdpPercap, y = lifeExp, size = pop, colour = continent)) + geom_point(alpha = 0.7, show.legend = FALSE) + scale_size(range = c(2, 12)) + scale_x_log10() + labs(title = 'Year: {as.integer(frame_time)}', x = 'GDP per capita', y = 'life expectancy') + transition_time(year) + ease_aes('linear') # To render the animation, you would typically use `animate(p)` or `anim_save()` animate(p) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-44-1.gif) ::: ::: ## Create Maps with ggplot2 `ggplot2` can also be used to create maps. The `sf` package is commonly used for working with spatial data. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(sf) # Data from https://geojson-maps.kyd.au/ geoj_data <- read_sf("data/custom.geo.json") geoj_data_asia = geoj_data |> filter(continent == "Asia") ggplot() + geom_sf( data = geoj_data_asia, aes(fill = income_grp), linewidth = 0.2, color = "white", alpha = 1 ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-45-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: # 7. ggplot2 Extension Packages The `ggplot2` ecosystem is vast, with many extension packages that add new geoms, themes, and functionalities. ## patchwork: Combining Multiple Plots The `patchwork` package provides a simple and intuitive syntax for combining multiple `ggplot2` plots into a single graphic. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(patchwork) p1 <- ggplot(mtcars) + geom_point(aes(mpg, disp)) p2 <- ggplot(mtcars) + geom_boxplot(aes(gear, disp, group = gear)) p3 <- ggplot(mtcars) + geom_smooth(aes(disp, qsec)) p4 <- ggplot(mtcars) + geom_bar(aes(carb)) (p1 | p2 | p3) / p4 ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-46-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## legendry: Advanced Legend Customization The `legendry` package provides tools for creating more complex and customized legends. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # pak::pak('legendry') # Uncomment to install ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(legendry) base_plot <- ggplot(mpg, aes(displ, hwy, colour = cty)) + geom_point() + labs( x = "Engine displacement", y = "Highway miles per gallon", col = "City miles per gallon" ) + theme(axis.line = element_line()) # A partial guide to display a bracket efficient_bracket <- primitive_bracket( key = key_range_manual(start = 25, end = Inf, name = "Efficient"), bracket = "square", theme = theme( legend.text = element_text(angle = 90, hjust = 0.5), axis.text.y.left = element_text(angle = 90, hjust = 0.5) ) ) base_plot + guides(y = guide_axis_stack("axis", efficient_bracket)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](1-ggplot2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-48-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: # 8. Conclusion and Further Resources This document has provided a tour of the fundamental concepts and capabilities of `ggplot2`. By understanding the grammar of graphics, you can create a vast range of visualizations to explore and communicate your data. For more in-depth information, please refer to the following resources: - [ggplot2 Official Website](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/) - [R for Data Science, Chapter 3: Data Visualization](https://r4ds.had.co.nz/data-visualisation.html) - [RStudio ggplot2 Cheatsheet](https://rstudio.github.io/cheatsheets/html/data-transformation.html) - [The `patchwork` Package](https://patchwork.data-imaginist.com/) - [The `gganimate` Package](https://gganimate.com/) - [The `ggthemes` Package](https://yutannihilation.github.io/allYourFigureAreBelongToUs/ggthemes/) - [The `magick` Package](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/magick/vignettes/intro.html)
